bother.translation[0].definitions[0].typ: intransitive, transitive usually in questions and negatives
bother.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to make the effort to do something
bother.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Why bother to go abroad, when there are so many nice places here?
‘Do you want me to wait for you?’ ‘No, don’t bother.’
He didn’t bother to answer the question.
He didn’t bother with a reply.
Many young people didn’t bother voting.
bother.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to make someone feel slightly worried, upset, or concerned
bother.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Being in a crowd really bothers me.
It was very noisy, but that didn’t bother me.
I try not to bother about what other people think.
It really bothered me that he’d forgotten my birthday.
bother.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to annoy someone, especially by interrupting them when they are trying to do something
bother.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Danny, don’t bother Ellen while she’s reading.
Would it bother you if I put on some music?
It didn’t seem worth bothering the doctor about.
bother.translation[0].definitions[3].def: if a part of your body bothers you, it is slightly painful or uncomfortable
bother.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to upset or frighten someone by talking to them when they do not want to talk to you, trying to hurt them, touch them sexually etc
bother.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: Don’t worry – my dog won’t bother you.
If he starts bothering you, let me know.
bother.translation[1].definitions[0].def: trouble or difficulty that has been caused by small problems and that usually only continues for a short time
bother.translation[1].definitions[0].not: something is more bother than it’s worth (=it is too difficult to be worth doing)
bother.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: It’s an old car, but it’s never caused me any bother.
‘Thanks for your help.’ ‘It was no bother  (=used to emphasize that you were happy to help someone) at all.’
My mother hardly ever went to the bother of  (=the effort of) making cakes.
Are you sure the station is on your way? I don’t want to give you any extra bother.
I should have phoned the shop first and saved myself the bother of going there.
Joe’s been having a bit of bother with his back again.
bother.translation[2].definitions[0].def: used when you are slightly annoyed
bother.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Oh bother! I forgot to phone Jean.
